Articles.Content: I've been to the poles, midlands, and highlands, so one can only assume there are lowlands too. Before I head over there, I'd just like to know if they exist and if so where they are. Are they in the big, dark craters? And are there any other science areas on the Mun? Finally, do all planets and moons have their own science areas and do they all follow this format (i.e. lowlands, midlands highlands, poles)?
There is an east crater, so I assume there is a north and a west.

There is an east crater, so I assume there is a north and a west.

Sorry, not sure what you mean. I'm talking about the different areas where you can collect science. Each area (midlands, highlands, etc.) counts as a separate scientific experiment kinda thing where they all grant the same amount of science even if you have visited one of the other parts. That's what I'm referring to.

Each large crater on the Mun is a biome, the canyons near one of the craters also count as a biome.

Low orbit allows you to make an EVA report about a biome on the Mun and Kerbin (although it's a little dangerous on kerbin).

The other planets seem to have only surface biomes and low / high altitude biomes aside from Eve which has a sea / land divide.

There may be a polar biome on Duna but I haven't found it yet. (one would think it would be simple enough....)
Look at the Mun, there are at least Three big craters on it. One of the is for sure label east moon crater biome, I know since I landed in it.

Here is a list of all the biomes in KSP:

http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Biome

People, use the search function, don't wait to be spoonfed.

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/53567-List-of-places-and-biomes-in-v0-22-%28Kerbal-planetary-geology-and-geography%29
